title: Polynomial Classification Game
description: Identify and classify algebraic expressions as monomials, binomials, trinomials, or non-polynomials

levels.name: Clear Examples
levels.description: Simple polynomials with obvious term counts

levels.name: Coefficients & Exponents
levels.description: More complex coefficients and higher powers

levels.name: Tricky Cases
levels.description: Watch out for negative and fractional exponents!

levels.name: Multiple Variables
levels.description: Polynomials with more than one variable

expressions.explanation: This expression has only ONE term: 5x. A single term makes it a monomial (mono = one).
expressions.hint: Count the number of parts separated by + or - signs.

expressions.explanation: This expression has TWO terms: x and 3. Two terms make it a binomial (bi = two).
expressions.hint: Look for the + sign that separates the terms.

expressions.explanation: This expression has THREE terms: x², 2x, and 1. Three terms make it a trinomial (tri = three).
expressions.hint: Count each part separated by + or - signs.

expressions.explanation: A constant like 7 is still a single term, making it a monomial. (Think of it as 7x⁰)
expressions.hint: Even a single number counts as one term.

expressions.explanation: This has TWO terms: x² and -4. The subtraction creates two separate terms, making it a binomial.
expressions.hint: Subtraction also separates terms, just like addition.

expressions.explanation: This has THREE terms: 3x, 2y, and -5. Three terms make it a trinomial.
expressions.hint: Count each part separated by + or - signs.

expressions.explanation: Even with a high exponent, x³ is still just ONE term, making it a monomial.
expressions.hint: The exponent doesn't add more terms.

expressions.explanation: This has TWO terms: 2x and -7. Two terms make it a binomial.
expressions.hint: Subtraction separates terms just like addition.

expressions.explanation: Despite the negative coefficient, this is still ONE term: -3x². A single term means it's a monomial.
expressions.hint: The negative sign is part of the coefficient, not a subtraction operation.

expressions.explanation: This has TWO terms: 4x³ and -7x. Two terms make it a binomial.
expressions.hint: Count the terms separated by the subtraction.

expressions.explanation: This has THREE terms: 2a², 5a, and -3. Three terms make it a trinomial.
expressions.hint: Variables other than x work the same way!

expressions.explanation: This is ONE term with a fractional coefficient (½). It's still a monomial because there's only one term.
expressions.hint: Fractional coefficients are allowed in polynomials.

expressions.explanation: This has THREE terms: -5x², 3x, and -8. Three terms make it a trinomial.
expressions.hint: Count each separate part.

expressions.explanation: This has TWO terms: x⁵ and x³. Two terms make it a binomial.
expressions.hint: Each power of x that's added is a separate term.

expressions.explanation: This is ONE term: 9y⁴. A single term makes it a monomial.
expressions.hint: Any variable with a coefficient is still just one term.

expressions.explanation: Wait! -2x + x simplifies to -x. So after combining like terms, we have x² - x - 2, which has THREE terms.
expressions.hint: Remember to combine like terms first!

expressions.explanation: This is NOT a polynomial! The term 1/x equals x⁻¹, which has a negative exponent. Polynomials can only have non-negative integer exponents.
expressions.hint: Rewrite 1/x as x⁻¹. Are negative exponents allowed in polynomials?

expressions.explanation: This is NOT a polynomial! The term √x equals x^(1/2), which has a fractional exponent. Polynomials require non-negative INTEGER exponents.
expressions.hint: Rewrite √x as x^(1/2). Are fractional exponents allowed?

expressions.explanation: This IS a polynomial! x⁰ = 1, which is a constant. Zero is a valid non-negative integer exponent, so this is a monomial.
expressions.hint: What does x⁰ equal? Is 0 a valid exponent for polynomials?

expressions.explanation: This is NOT a polynomial! The term x⁻² has a negative exponent. Polynomials must have non-negative integer exponents only.
expressions.hint: Check if all exponents are non-negative integers.

expressions.explanation: This is NOT a polynomial! The exponent 2.5 is not an integer. Polynomial exponents must be non-negative INTEGERS (0, 1, 2, 3, ...).
expressions.hint: Is 2.5 an integer?

expressions.explanation: This IS a polynomial! Dividing by a constant (2) is fine. This equals ½x² + (3/2)x, which has two terms - a binomial!
expressions.hint: Dividing by a constant is allowed. What if you distribute the division?

expressions.explanation: This is NOT a polynomial! While x³ is fine, 1/x² = x⁻² has a negative exponent. ALL terms must have valid exponents.
expressions.hint: Check each term separately. What is 1/x² as a power of x?

expressions.explanation: This IS a polynomial! The coefficients π and e are just irrational numbers - that's perfectly fine. Two terms make it a binomial.
expressions.hint: Irrational coefficients are allowed. Count the terms.

expressions.explanation: This is ONE term with two variables. Even with multiple variables, it's still a monomial because there's only one term.
expressions.hint: Multiple variables in ONE term still make it a single term.

expressions.explanation: This has TWO terms: x²y and xy². Two terms make it a binomial, regardless of how many variables are in each term.
expressions.hint: Count the terms separated by + or - signs.

expressions.explanation: This has THREE terms: a², 2ab, and b². This is actually (a + b)² expanded! Three terms make it a trinomial.
expressions.hint: Count each part. This is a famous pattern!

expressions.explanation: Even with THREE variables, this is still ONE term. A single term with any number of variables is still a monomial.
expressions.hint: How many separate parts are added or subtracted?

expressions.explanation: This has THREE terms: xy, xz, and yz. Three terms make it a trinomial.
expressions.hint: Count the parts separated by + signs.

expressions.explanation: This is NOT a polynomial! The term x/y equals xy⁻¹, which has y with a negative exponent. Variables must have non-negative integer exponents.
expressions.hint: What happens when you divide by a variable?

expressions.explanation: This has TWO terms: a³ and -b³. This is the 'difference of cubes' pattern! Two terms make it a binomial.
expressions.hint: Count the terms. This is a special factoring pattern.

expressions.explanation: This has THREE terms with mixed variables: 2x²y, -3xy², and 5xy. Three terms make it a trinomial.
expressions.hint: Count each separate term with its coefficient.

incorrect: Not quite - check the term count!
Close! Remember to check exponents too.
Good try! This one is tricky.

tips: Count terms by looking for + and - signs that separate parts
A negative in front of a term is part of the coefficient, not a separator
Polynomials can ONLY have non-negative integer exponents (0, 1, 2, 3, ...)
Watch out for hidden negative exponents: 1/x = x⁻¹
Fractional exponents like √x = x^(1/2) are NOT allowed in polynomials
Multiple variables in ONE term still make it a single term

excellent.subMessage: You classify expressions like a pro!

fair.subMessage: Keep practicing term counting and exponent checking.

needsWork.subMessage: Focus on counting terms and checking exponent rules.
